content: why lock here welcome back well summer's over let's enjoy what
little warmth is left and talk about lava tiles so at first I basically tried
to do water tiles from episode 13 but paint them up with yellow orange and red
and you can see it just doesn't look very good maybe I did this in reverse
order and it should have been red orange yellow but I decided to just try a
different tact and this is what I came up with make a standard foundation two
and a half light by two and a half light and apply corrugation planning apply a
thick coat white PVA glue not watered down
add some pebbles and now add sand do not go for full coverage like we do with our
minis try and hit some spots heavy others not at all and randomly in
between as shown here let it dry and because this is double
corrugated cardboard I did not have any warping problems whatsoever apply a
solid base coat of yellow if you're using a really terrible paint like I am
it might take two or even three coats apply a strong dry brush of orange
apply a light dry brush of red apply just a dusting of black hit mostly the
pebbles with it and then maybe a couple other spots
all right for our demonstration we're gonna look at the lair of a young red
dragon so what have we really done here all I've done is taken the hot coals
effect from the blacksmith Forge in episode 19 and covered an entire tile
with it and that itself really is just Scotty's method for rubble in a cave but
with his fire kit applied to it and I love the paint job here just you can see
the heat coming off of it it really is striking in person and in on video so I
like this a lot better these are not supposed to be playable because they're
lava so it's okay that they're a little rough and miniature would likely not sit
flat on it so I am why lock thank you for joining
me and I'll see you next time you
